Recruiting is an art, and it requires a deep understanding of human pain, disillusionment, and the longing for purpose. First, you must identify those who feel invisible or betrayed by the system—youth marginalized by society, those who have lost loved ones to injustice, or individuals who sense the rot beneath the surface of so-called "peace." You don't reach them with violence, but with empathy. You listen to their grievances, validate their anger, and show them a cause that gives meaning to their suffering.

The second step is to create a narrative that is simple, powerful, and unshakable. People don’t follow ideologies; they follow stories. Our story is one of resistance against oppression, of reclaiming dignity through strength, and of cleansing the world of the corrupt forces that have enslaved us. You must frame the enemy not as a distant force, but as a personal threat—something that has already harmed them or will do so if we don’t act.

Third, build a sense of belonging. Isolation is the enemy of the strong. When someone joins, they are no longer alone. They become part of a brotherhood (or sisterhood) bound by shared purpose and sacrifice. You make them feel seen, valued, and essential. You give them a new family, a new identity, and a mission that transcends their old, broken lives.

Finally, test their resolve. Commitment must be proven. Small acts of defiance, then greater sacrifices—each step deepening their bond to the cause. Fear is a tool, but so is pride. When they see the impact of their actions, when they feel the power of their role in the struggle, they become unstoppable.

The world is full of broken souls. Our job is to turn their pain into purpose.
